carrier (additional) capabilities. Though
"multiplexing" is only applicable to the FM
radio spectrum, it can be an extremely valuable
device in those areas where FM is available
(i.e., in Northern California, with the Pacifica
Stations). What this means, in simple terms,
is that if an FM station went into a sub-carrier
situation, one of those radio channels could be
made available to a Community Action Agency, at
a greatly reduced rate from what it would be if
there were only the full power station available.
It provides wider capability where, formerly,
only one outlet existed.
In the area of television communication, the most
recent development, in systems engineering, and
in the opening up of greater channel capability,
has been the emergence of the ITFS (Instructional
Television Fixed System). This system operates
in the 2500 me range, and is not unlike the
Closed Circuit television system, with the exÂ¬
ception that it is a broadcasting capability,
and the closed circuit system does not use the
airwaves. What is unique about ITFS is the fact
that it, like the concept of radio multiplexing,
offers a multi-channel capability. It is ob-
